items.title: We're taking a few weeks off, but..
items.content:
#â€‹652 â€” August 17, 2023

Read on the Web

ğŸï¸ I'm taking two weeks off and will be back on Thursday, September 7. So if you don't see the newsletter turn up for a while, it's our faultÂ ;-) As I've had to produce much of this issue a few days in advance, I'm mixing in some 'golden oldies' and popular items from earlier this year to keep things interesting, so this is a less newsy issue than usual. See you again inÂ September!Â ğŸ‘‹
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

How Dropbox Reduced the Size of Its JavaScript Bundles by 33% â€” The folks at Dropbox realize that when youâ€™re operating at scale, small annoyances and delays add up, and their web perf team narrowed down some of Dropboxâ€™s perf issues to their module bundlingÂ process.

Nadeem and Hong (Dropbox)

htmx is Part of the GitHub Accelerator â€” htmx is a perfect example of a library that isnâ€™t brand new, but one that becomes popular once the time is right. Its success is only continuing following acceptance into the first class of GitHubâ€™s open-source Accelerator initiative, an opportunity that will enable the development of htmx 2.0. GitHubÂ repo.

Big Sky Software

You Might Not Need a Framework â€” Maximiliano Firtman shares the vanilla approach in this video course on building rich web apps and sites without depending on libraries of frameworks. It covers the DOM, event handling, routing, web components, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

You Don't (May Not) Need Lodash or Underscore â€” Inspired by the popular You Might Not Need jQuery, this extensive document provides pure JavaScript alternatives to almost 100 different functions as youâ€™d find in popular utility libraries like Lodash.

You Don't Need

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • It's still a few weeks away, but we're told "Bun 1.0 is almost here" and there's ğŸ“… a live presentation by Bun's creator, Jarred Sumner, on September 7 you can sign up for now.

  • If you like to keep up with other languages than JavaScript, renowned C++ expert Herb Sutter recently â–¶ï¸ gave a fantastic talk about modernizing and improving C++ more quickly by creating a Typescript-esque superset with better abstractions and features.

  • ğŸ•¹ React Jam was a React-oriented gamejam that took place last week and here are the winning games.

  • ğŸ‘¾ Talking of gaming, the annual js13kGames JS coding competition has just started. You can join in the fun, though, as it doesn't end till September 13.

  • Robin Wieruch shared his 10 Web development trends in 2023 back in January â€“ how are they shaping up so far? As Larry David might say.. pretty, pretty good.

  • In "The â€œSkeleton Squadâ€ is now targeting NPM", the team at Socket take a look at how a group is attacking the npm package ecosystem.

  • ğŸ¦â–¶ï¸ Playing with the earliest JavaScript in Netscape 2.0.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Fresh 1.4
    â†³ The Deno-powered web framework.

  • jest-dom 6.0
    â†³ Custom matchers to test the state of the DOM.

  • NodeBB 3.3 â€“ Node.js-powered forum software.

  • Electron 26.0

  • Angular 16.2

  • Playwright 1.37.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Discover three.js: A Complete Guide to Creating 3D Web Experiences â€” The breadth of the content on offer here had me looking for the price, but itâ€™s all online and free. Thereâ€™s a lot to dig through here if you want to get started (or just get better) at using three.js. If youâ€™re already familiar with three.js, you may enjoy the three.js tips and tricksÂ page.

Lewy Blue

JSX Without React â€” Exploring a new tool called NakedJSX that will allow you to render JSX without the need for the full ReactÂ framework.

Chris Coyier

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Youâ€™ve Got Options for Removing Event Listeners â€” Reviewing some of the most common approaches available to remove event listeners inÂ JavaScript.

Alex MacArthur

Prepare Your Firefox Desktop Extension for the Upcoming AndroidÂ Release â€” â€œFirefox will become the only major Android browser to support an open extensionÂ ecosystem.â€

Scott DeVaney (Mozilla)

Application State Management with Angular Signals
Yevgeny / Oz

â–¶Â Â Six (or so) New Approved and Proposed JavaScript APIs
Syntax Pocast podcast

The Importance of Verifying Webhook Signatures
Marcelo Oliveira (Snyk)

Writing JavaScript Without a Build System
Julia Evans

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Croner 7.0: Cron for JavaScript and TypeScript â€” Trigger functions upon the schedule of your choice using the classic cron syntax. Works in Node, Deno, Bun and the browser, across time zones, offers error handling and overrun protection, and more. Thereâ€™s an live demo on JSFiddle. v7.0 adds support for specifying the n-thÂ weekday.

Hexagon

Linkify 4.1: Link Up URLs, Email Addresses, and More in Plain Text â€” Given some plain text containing things like links and emails, Linkify will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. Not just URLs or emails, but hashtags, @mentions, IP addresses, and more â€“ see the homepage for examples. GitHubÂ repo.

Hypercontext

ğŸ¦˜JavaScript Scratchpad for VS Code: New Logpoints Feature! â€” Seeing runtime values has never been so easy. Simply place a breakpoint on a line, no debugger required: zeroÂ setup/configuration.

Wallaby.js sponsor

deno_python: Python Interpreter Bindings for Deno â€” A seamless Deno-Python integration via the Python/C API. The latest release supports installing and importing pip packages. This feature has been described as â€œslightly cursedâ€ but itâ€™s certainlyÂ interesting.

Denosaurs

Tagger: A Zero Dependency, Vanilla JavaScript Tagging Library â€” You can play with a live demoÂ here.

Jakub T. Jankiewicz

Over 100 Algorithms and Data Structures Demonstrated in JS â€” Examples of many common algorithms (e.g. bit manipulation, Pascalâ€™s triangle, Hamming distance) and data structures (e.g. linked lists, tries, graphs) with explanations. Available in other languages too like Chinese, Korean, French, andÂ Spanish.

Oleksii Trekhleb et al.

Deliver Interactive Real-Time Live Streams with Amazon IVS

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

Proto Tree: A Way to Observe the JS Prototype Chain â€” Gal explains the motivation for this tool in ğŸ¦ this TwitterÂ thread.

Gal Weizman

Barba.js: For Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages â€” You certainly canâ€™t say the projectâ€™s homepage doesnâ€™t show off all of its features. For such a dramatic set of effects, things feel smooth and surprisingly nice ğŸ˜ GitHubÂ repo.

De Rosa, Michel, et al.

Stritch: A JavaScript Barcode Scanning Library â€” Itâ€™s a commercial library, but featureful and well presented with support for a variety of 1D and 2D barcodeÂ types.

Pixelverse LLC

#Script: A JS-Inspired Scripting Language for .NET â€” An embeddable scripting language mostly targeting template use cases. It can also be used in a LispÂ style.

ServiceStack

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

ngraph.path: Path Finding Through Graphs â€” Thereâ€™s a live demo if you want to see how it tackles the road network of several globalÂ cities.

Andrei Kashcha

  • SVGR 8.1
    â†³ Transform SVGs into React components.

  • BlockNote 0.9
    â†³ "Notion-style" block-based editor built atop Prosemirror. (Demo)

  • React Number Format 5.3
    â†³ Input formatter library for numbers.

  • Tinypool 0.8
    â†³ Minimal/tiny Node.js worker thread pool.

  • melonJS 15.9 â€“ Lightweight HTML5 game engine.

  • Sortable 2.3 â€“ Vanilla JS table sort. (Demo)

  • Preact 10.17.0

ğŸ˜­ Last week I promised a JavaScript AI/ML feature, but time hasn't worked out in my favor (note to self: don't send an issue while on vacation ğŸ˜†). Keep your fingers crossed and it'll be in one of the next issues. So much has been happening in the JavaScript AI/ML space that we want to shine a spotlight on it sooner than later.

ğŸ‘‹ We'll be back in three weeks on September 7, 2023. See you soon! If you have anything to submit for the next issue, hit reply and let us know (but appreciate we may be slow to reply since we'll be on vacation ğŸ˜‰).

items.title: Svelte 5 is going to be radical
items.content:
#â€‹651 â€” August 10, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

My Experience Modernizing Packages to ESM â€” What a post! Mark, well known for his work on React, Redux, and much more, details the painful experiences and hard-earned lessons he picked up while migrating the Redux packages toÂ ESÂ modules.

Mark 'acemarke' Erikson

Things You Forgot (or Never Knew) Because of React â€” â€œIâ€™ve written before about how React is the new default frontend framework, and how I donâ€™t think most people using React on a regular basis realize quite how much itâ€™s fallen behind.â€ High level thoughts about the React â€˜bubbleâ€™ and some reasons to look beyond it, including a round up of some of the alternativeÂ options.

Josh Collinsworth

Build Web Apps in 60 Seconds with DynaboardÂ AI â€” Dynaboard's low-code IDE offers 40+ built-in UI components. Quickly connect to REST & GraphQL APIs, SQL databases, and spreadsheets. Write custom code or use AI to generate any SQL, JS, orÂ CSS.

Dynaboard sponsor

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • "Svelte 5 is going to be radical," ğŸ¦ tweets Rich Harris.

  • Server side JS runtime Deno 1.36 has been released with extended security options, a polyfill for node:test, completion of the node:os polyfill, and many other minor Node.js compatibility improvements.

  • Google has unveiled a sneak peek of a new IDE it's developing called Project IDX. It has VS Code at its base but with strong JS framework support, simulators, and lot of 'AI smarts' on top, ğŸ¦ says Addy Osmani.

  • A revived but early stage proposal for introducing observables to JavaScript. Your feedback is sought, so file an issue if you have any.

  • A fun walk through front-end history with a blog post containing every HTML element (well, almost â€“ sorry applet).

  • Nim 2.0 has been released. Nim is a C++ and Python inspired, statically typed systems language, that supports being compiled to JavaScript.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.2 RC â€“ TS 5.2 is nearly set for its final release. Explicit resource management with using is the headline feature, but there's more, as usual.

  • esbuild 0.19.0 â€“ The high-perf bundler can now import paths containing wildcards and supports advanced CSS @import rules. Note that this release contains backwards-incompatible changes.

  • Astro 2.10 â€“ There's also a first beta of Astro 3.

  • Node.js Security Releases â€“ v20.5.1 (Current), v18.17.1 (LTS) and v16.20.2 (LTS) are all part of this set of releases including OpenSSL security updates and fixes, mostly, around permission policies.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Bringing Sharp to WebAssembly and WebContainers â€” A look at how itâ€™s possible to bring Sharp, a popular Node.js image manipulation module, into the browser. Welcome to theÂ future.

Ingvar Stepanyan

A Compilation of Outstanding JS Testing Articles â€” An opinionated list of 10 outstanding testing articles, all with a JS slant to them. He also mentions his own list of JavaScript and Node.js Testing Best Practices which is worth revisitingÂ too.

Yoni Goldberg

ğŸš€ JavaScript Moves Fastâ€”and So Should You. Let Us Help YouÂ Upgrade â€” React, Vue, Next, Node - our expert devs have it covered! Technical debt mounting? We're your tech debt busters!Â ğŸ‘Š

Reduce Tech Debt. UpgradeJS now. sponsor

â–¶Â Â A Look at HTMX: A 'Game-Changing' Alternative to React? â€” One of Jackâ€™s typically well produced, short tours (just 14-minutes). He likes htmx and thinks itâ€™s worth learning in order to have more options in yourÂ toolbox.

Jack Herrington

ğŸ“ Prefer a traditional writeup? James Hibbard has one here.

Node.js's 'Config Hell' Problem â€” Andy ponders why a Next.js project has over 30 configuration files and what we can do to avoid it (unsurprisingly, it involves using Deno, but I enjoy theÂ boldness).

Andy Jiang (Deno)

Creating a Screen + Camera Recorder with the Document Picture-in-PictureÂ API â€” This is more powerful than I was expecting. You can basically record a screencast using browser APIs. In Chrome, atÂ least.

SÃ©bastien Jalliffier Verne

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity

Userfront sponsor

â–¶Â Â Build and Deploy a Full Stack MERN Next.js 13 Threads Clone â€” An extensive, five hour screencast walking through the creation of a Threads/Twitter/X-style app using Next.js 13 and Clerk for userÂ management.

Adrian Hajdin

â–¶Â Â Turbopack vs Webpack â€” Being involved with the development of both bundlers, Tobias Koppers has some interesting things to say about the differences and explains why Turbopack isÂ necessary.

Tobias Koppers and Jack Herrington

Autogenerating Rust-JS Bindings with UniFFI
Ben Dean-Kawamura (Mozilla)

Migrating My Blog from Gatsby to Astro
Artem Sapegin

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Fuite 3.0: A Tool for Finding Memory Leaks in Web Apps â€” A CLI tool that you can point at any URL to analyze for memory leaks. Introductory blog post here, and thereâ€™s also a videoÂ tutorial.

Nolan Lawson

Luxon 3.4: Date and Time Manipulation Library â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Moment.js, itâ€™s like that but with immutable objects, 1-indexed months, Intl-powered localization (so no locale or timezone files needed) andÂ more.

Moment.js

JavaScript Frontend Error Monitoring 101 â€” Take a crash (pun intended) course on frontend error monitoring with Sentry. ReadÂ on.

Sentry sponsor

Filesize.js: Generate Human Readable Strings From File Sizes â€” For example, 123456 bytes could turn into "120.56 KB" - though different standards of conversion can also be used. GitHubÂ repo.

Jason Mulligan

Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly â€” An intriguing project where you â€˜drawâ€™ diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these get rendered into much nicer looking versions. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for yourÂ needs.

Sam Goto / Google

ğŸ’¡ Talking of Mermaid, the latest release supports SankeyÂ diagrams.

d3-graphviz 5.1: Graphviz DOT Rendering and Animated Transitions â€” Renders SVGs from DOT-defined graphs using a WebAssembly port ofÂ Graphviz, a popular graph visualizationÂ tool.

Magnus Jacobsson

ğŸ”ŠÂ Meyda: Audio Feature Extraction Library â€” Supports both offline feature extraction as well as real-time feature extraction using the Web Audio API. You can play with a demo right on theÂ homepage.

Rawlinson, Segal, Fiala, Wray, et al.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

Senior Software Engineer (Frontend Lead) â€” Lead Emerge's web platform, used by teams like DoorDash, Square, & Airbnb (Our stack: Next.js, React, TS,Â Vercel).
ğŸ›¸ Emerge Tools

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

ggml.js: Run ggml-Ported ML Models Directly in Your Browser â€” We're going to do a feature on ML/AI related stuff in JS next week, so watch this space..

Rahul D Shetty

  • React Virtuoso 4.5 â€“ Powerful virtual list component.

  • Perspective 2.4 â€“ Fast, streaming real-time data visualization.

  • express-rate-limit 6.9 â€“ Basic rate limiting for Express apps.

  • PLV8 3.2 â€“ Use JS as a procedural language in PostgreSQL.

  • Puppeteer 21.0 â€“ Headless Chrome automation in Node.js.

ğŸ“ŠÂ Well, that's handy..

npmgraph: A Fun Way to Visualize Package Dependency Graphs â€” A Web tool that accepts one or more package names (or a package.json) and renders a visualization of their (possibly intersecting) dependency graphs. Packages can be colored by various criteria (such as number of maintainers, if you want to see how fragile the world is) and you can download SVGs of theÂ output.

Kieffer, Brigante, et al.

ğŸš€ JavaScript Moves Fastâ€”and So Should You. Let Us Help YouÂ Upgrade â€” React, Vue, Next, Node - our expert devs have it covered! Technical debt mounting? We're your tech debt busters!Â ğŸ‘Š
Reduce Tech Debt. UpgradeJS now. sponsor


  
  
â–¶Â Â A Look at HTMX: A 'Game-Changing' Alternative to React? â€” One of Jackâ€™s typically well produced, short tours (just 14-minutes). He likes htmx and thinks itâ€™s worth learning in order to have more options in yourÂ toolbox.
Jack Herrington 


ğŸ“ Prefer a traditional writeup? James Hibbard has one here.





  
  
Node.js's 'Config Hell' Problem â€” Andy ponders why a Next.js project has over 30 configuration files and what we can do to avoid it (unsurprisingly, it involves using Deno, but I enjoy theÂ boldness).
Andy Jiang (Deno) 


  
  
Creating a Screen + Camera Recorder with the Document Picture-in-PictureÂ API â€” This is more powerful than I was expecting. You can basically record a screencast using browser APIs. In Chrome, atÂ least.
SÃ©bastien Jalliffier Verne 


  
  
React Authentication â€” Without Complexity
Userfront sponsor


  
  
â–¶Â Â Build and Deploy a Full Stack MERN Next.js 13 Threads Clone â€” An extensive, five hour screencast walking through the creation of a Threads/Twitter/X-style app using Next.js 13 and Clerk for userÂ management.
Adrian Hajdin 


  
  
â–¶Â Â Turbopack vs Webpack â€” Being involved with the development of both bundlers, Tobias Koppers has some interesting things to say about the differences and explains why Turbopack isÂ necessary.
Tobias Koppers and Jack Herrington 


  
Autogenerating Rust-JS Bindings with UniFFI
  
Ben Dean-Kawamura (Mozilla) 
  


  
Migrating My Blog from Gatsby to Astro
  
Artem Sapegin 
  


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools 




  





  
  
Fuite 3.0: A Tool for Finding Memory Leaks in Web Apps â€” A CLI tool that you can point at any URL to analyze for memory leaks. Introductory blog post here, and thereâ€™s also a videoÂ tutorial.
Nolan Lawson 


  
  
Luxon 3.4: Date and Time Manipulation Library â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Moment.js, itâ€™s like that but with immutable objects, 1-indexed months, Intl-powered localization (so no locale or timezone files needed) andÂ more.
Moment.js 


  
  
JavaScript Frontend Error Monitoring 101 â€” Take a crash (pun intended) course on frontend error monitoring with Sentry. ReadÂ on.
Sentry sponsor


  
  
Filesize.js: Generate Human Readable Strings From File Sizes â€” For example, 123456 bytes could turn into "120.56 KB" - though different standards of conversion can also be used. GitHubÂ repo.
Jason Mulligan 





  





  
  
Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly â€” An intriguing project where you â€˜drawâ€™ diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these get rendered into much nicer looking versions. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for yourÂ needs.
Sam Goto / Google 


ğŸ’¡ Talking of Mermaid, the latest release supports SankeyÂ diagrams.





  
  
d3-graphviz 5.1: Graphviz DOT Rendering and Animated Transitions â€” Renders SVGs from DOT-defined graphs using a WebAssembly port ofÂ Graphviz, a popular graph visualizationÂ tool.
Magnus Jacobsson 


  
  
ğŸ”ŠÂ Meyda: Audio Feature Extraction Library â€” Supports both offline feature extraction as well as real-time feature extraction using the Web Audio API. You can play with a demo right on theÂ homepage.
Rawlinson, Segal, Fiala, Wray, et al. 





ğŸ’» Jobs





  
Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
  
Hired 
  


  
Senior Software Engineer (Frontend Lead) â€” Lead Emerge's web platform, used by teams like DoorDash, Square, & Airbnb (Our stack: Next.js, React, TS,Â Vercel).
  
ğŸ›¸ Emerge Tools 
  


ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.













  
  
ggml.js: Run ggml-Ported ML Models Directly in Your Browser â€” We're going to do a feature on ML/AI related stuff in JS next week, so watch this space..
Rahul D Shetty 




React Virtuoso 4.5 â€“ Powerful virtual list component.
Perspective 2.4 â€“ Fast, streaming real-time data visualization.
express-rate-limit 6.9 â€“ Basic rate limiting for Express apps.
PLV8 3.2 â€“ Use JS as a procedural language in PostgreSQL.
Puppeteer 21.0 â€“ Headless Chrome automation in Node.js.


ğŸ“ŠÂ Well, that's handy.. 




  





  
  
npmgraph: A Fun Way to Visualize Package Dependency Graphs â€” A Web tool that accepts one or more package names (or a package.json) and renders a visualization of their (possibly intersecting) dependency graphs. Packages can be colored by various criteria (such as number of maintainers, if you want to see how fragile the world is) and you can download SVGs of theÂ output.
Kieffer, Brigante, et al.

items.title: Taking JavaScript into Python
items.content:
#â€‹650 â€” August 3, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Tale of Evading JavaScript Anti-Debugging Techniques â€” When youâ€™re poking arounddebugging code written and distributed by a third party, there might be some sneaky traps thrown in your path to prevent your usual techniques from working. What next? Disable breakpoints in DevTools? Use a proxy? What about.. recompiling your entire browser? ğŸ˜†

Veritas

This reminds me of the guy who scraped pages by dumping heap snapshots from the browser â€“ another fun post if you enjoy low level spelunking.

VanJS 1.0: A 1KB Reactive UI Framework Without React/JSX â€” VanJS is particularly light and elegant, and its author has put some serious effort into documenting it and offering tools to convert your HTML to its custom format. This weekâ€™s v1.0 release is a relatively big step forward for what is still a young project. GitHubÂ repo.

Tao Xin

Add Excel-Like Spreadsheet Features to Your JavaScript Apps: SpreadJS â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from GrapeCity sponsor

PythonMonkey: JavaScript/WASM Interop for Python â€” The alpha release of a new way to bring Python and JavaScript together, by way of embedding Mozilla SpiderMonkey into the Python VM. This post introduces the concept with some examples, an idea of where the project is headed, as well as some ColabÂ demos. GitHub repo.

Will Pringle

dnt: A Tool to Publish a Hybrid npm Module for ESM and CommonJS â€” From the Deno team comes a tool that lets you write modules in JavaScript or TypeScript and then transforms them to support CommonJS, ESM, browsers, Deno, Node, andÂ more.

Andy Jiang (Deno)

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ§ The popular Syntax.fm podcast has had a run of interesting episodes lately covering topics like the idea of â–¶ï¸ server-side JavaScript standards, â–¶ï¸ Rust for JavaScript developers, and â–¶ï¸ the role of polyfills.

  • A social engineering campaign that targets tech employees has been spreading through npm malware, claims Feross Aboukhadijeh of Socket.

  • Radix UI is now available in Vue thanks to Radix Vue.

  • Google has unveiled some big improvements to how the Google Maps JavaScript code can be loaded.

  • Firefox 116's DevTools now support Custom Object formatters. This feature, long supported by Chrome, lets sites determine how certain types of object representation are formatted in the console andÂ debugger.

  • The Svelte project has posted its latest monthly update. There's a lot going on in the Svelte world right now.

Logging and Tracing Re-invented. Stop Sampling, Get Axiom â€”
â€œIn the beginning there was stdoutâ€¦.â€ Get started for free, or get 1tb forÂ $25/mo.

Axiom sponsor

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Backbone 1.5 â€“ Yes. Really. And it's still a thing of beauty.

  • Shoelace 2.6 â€“ Popular suite of agnostic UI Web Components.

  • Prisma 5.1 â€“ Next-gen Node.js + TypeScript ORM.

  • eslint-config-prettier 8.10 â€“ Turn off ESLint rules that clash with Prettier.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Understanding React Server Components â€” If youâ€™ve struggled to get your head around the ideas involved, and Dan Abramovâ€™s â€˜letâ€™s recreate RSCs from scratchâ€™ went too deep, this is a good, high-level explanation of the fundamentals covering what problems RSCs solve, why you might use them, and how Next.js makes it allÂ easier.

Alice Moore (Vercel)

Type vs Interface: Which Should You Use in 2023? â€” Learn the key differences between interfaces and type aliases in TypeScript, including their use cases and important features toÂ consider.

Matt Pocock

How to Build a Multilanguage Website with Next.js & Storyblok

Storyblok sponsor

Speeding Up V8 Heap Snapshots â€” When diagnosing a memory leak in a JavaScript app, engineers at Bloomberg encountered some weird performance issues with capturing a single full-size heapshot taking more than 30 minutes(!) at times. Hereâ€™s the full story of how they investigated and resolved theÂ problem.

JosÃ© Dapena Paz (Igalia)

'If Web Components Are So Great, Why Am I Not Using Them?' â€” Do Web Components have a marketing problem? Dave thinks so, and shares what he thinks the issues are for this slowly-adoptedÂ technology.

Dave Rupert

â–¶Â Â How to Build a Drag-and-Drop Kanban Board â€” A complete screencast walkthrough of using React to build a Trello-like app based around the familiar Kanban board pattern. It also serves as an introduction to the dnd-kit drag-and-dropÂ toolkit.

Kliton Bare

An Introduction to Quicksort â€” A good, beginner friendly introduction to the Quicksort algorithm, concluding with a JavaScript implementation. (Beware the floating burgerÂ though..)

Kirupa Chinnathambi

Everything Mux Learnt Migrating 50K Lines of Code to React ServerÂ Components
Darius Cepulis (Mux)

â–¶Â Â Refactoring an Angular App to Modern NgRx â€” NgRx is a reactive state management approach for Angular.
Marko Stanimirovic

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

tsup 7.2: Bundle Your TypeScript Library with No Config â€” Throw your .js, .json, .mjs, .ts, and .tsx files at the esbuild-powered tsup and say hello to transpiled, bundled code for distribution. More in thisÂ tutorial.

egoist

Vite React Boilerplate: A Production Ready Starter Template â€” A new â€˜batteries includedâ€™ Vite + React app template that leans upon, well, a lot of batteries from Zustand to Zod toÂ Storybook.

Ricardo Valdovinos

Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You'reÂ welcome.

FusionAuth sponsor

Hackathon Starter 8.0: A Boilerplate for Node Web Apps â€” For when you might want to start building a Node app quickly (like at a hackathon, say) including key features like auth/OAuth, Bootstrap 5, account management, emailÂ forms..

Sahat Yalkabov

OGL 1.0: A Minimal WebGL Framework â€” WebGL is far from the easiest technology to use on its own, so libraries like Three.js are often used to make it more accessible. OGL has a similar motive to Three.js while remaining far closer to the WebGLÂ metal.

Nathan Gordon et al.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Senior Software Engineer (Frontend Lead) â€” Come lead Emerge's web platform, used by teams like DoorDash, Square, Dropbox & Airbnb (our stack: Next.js, React, TS,Â Vercel).
ğŸ›¸ Emerge Tools

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

Size Limit 8.2: JavaScript Performance Budgeting Tool â€” Calculate the real â€˜costâ€™ to run your JS app or lib and maintain an eye on performance and raise the alarm (in your CI system, say) when things go awry. Supports ES modules and treeÂ shaking.

Andrey Sitnik

  • Stockfish.js 16 â€“ The famous Stockfish chess engine in JS via WASM.

  • Marked 6.0 â€“ Fast Markdown parser and compiler. Now rewritten in TypeScript.

  • eta (Î·) 3.1 â€“ Embedded JS template engine. Now with Bun support.

  • Tremor 3.6 â€“ React library for building dashboards.

  • Octokit.js 3.1 â€“ 'Batteries-included' GitHub SDK.

  • React Image Gallery 1.3 â€“ Image gallery carousel component.

  • YouTube.js 5.8 â€“ Library to use YouTube's private API.

ğŸ´Â Let's hit the Oregon Trail

The Oregon Trail was a 2000+ mile wagon route used by traders and migrants headed west in the early days of the United States. It was also a hugely popular computer game that, more often than not, ended in disaster for the virtual settlers whose lives you directed.

Particularly popular on the Apple II and early Macs, you can give the game a spin via the following project:

Macintosh.js: A Virtual Macintosh Running via Electron â€” An impressive virtual machine emulating a 1991 Macintosh Quadra 900 with System 8, all running in Electron. We linked to this several years ago but itâ€™s had some updates since then and runs faster than before. As well as a few games, such as Oregon Trail, there are a variety of apps pre-installed, including a trial of Adobe Photoshop 3 which starts up faster than my real PhotoshopÂ now.. (Download necessary since it's an Electron app and all..)

Felix Rieseberg, Apple, et al.

items.title: Name mangling
items.content:
#â€‹649 â€” July 27, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Hono + Htmx + Cloudflare: A New Stack? â€” A lot of people seem to be jumping on htmx lately as an alternative to the complexity of frameworks like React, but what if you want to keep using JSX? Hono is a (vaguely Express-like) Web framework targeting edge function use cases and includes middleware for rendering JSX. Yusuke gives a quick example of how all this can come together with Cloudflare Workers and D1 for a simpler, full-stack JSÂ experience.

Yusuke Wada

Shrinking VS Code with Name Mangling â€” Thereâ€™s a fair bit of JavaScript in VS Code but the team has managed to reduce the size of the shipped code by almost 4MB without actually doing any deleting or refactoring thanks to a new â€˜name manglingâ€™ build step. This is a great read on how the team approached things and got itÂ working.

Matt Bierner

New Course: The Hard Parts of UI Development â€” Develop an under-the-hood knowledge of UI development by learning techniques such as data binding, UI composition, templating, virtual DOM and its reconciliation, and hooks, all fromÂ scratch!

Frontend Masters sponsor

Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses â€” A new project with some prominent names attached (the designer of C# and PM for TypeScript, for starters) that demonstrates the excitement within MS for large language models (LLMs). TypeChat aims to work around the problem of LLMs outputting hard-to-parse natural language and to direct such output into a predictable, typed form.

Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al.

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¦ React/Redux's Dan Abramov is leaving Meta. Having achieved so much and reaching a point where he feels ready to move on, Dan is departing Meta but will remain on the React team as an independent thirdÂ party.Â ğŸ’™

  • ğŸ“˜ The Concise TypeScript Book is, unsurprisingly, a guide to using TypeScript. More surprisingly, it's all on GitHub and free to read. Hurrah.

  • Tixy is an interactive page for learning logic, math and expressions by solving puzzles using a visual grid. It starts off very simply, but gets elaborate quickly. This is a neat way to pick up some of the skills needed forÂ Dwitter.

  • JSPlayground is a new Web-based JavaScript sandbox tool.

  • Is the term 'Jamstack' finished? Brian Rinaldi wonders.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Bun 0.7 â€“ The JavaScriptCore-based alternative JS runtime adds (experimental) Vite support, Web Workers support, and includes a --smol option to run in memory constrained environments (with a significant memory reduction shown off in theÂ post).

  • Astro 2.9 â€“ The 'zero JS by default' framework adds experimental support for view transitions and more.

  • Neutralinojs v4.13.0 â€“ Lightweight cross-platform desktop app framework.

  • Remix 1.19 â€“ Modern full-stack JS framework.

  • Node.js v20.5.0 (Current)

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ğŸ’› Â 'Good Code is Like a Love Letter to The Next Developer Who Will MaintainÂ It' â€” â€œThe beauty of our creations, however, is not judged solely by the elegance of our algorithms or the efficiency of our code, but by the joy and ease with which others can build upon ourÂ work.â€

Addy Osmani

More practically, Addy also tells us to stick to 'boring architecture' for as long as possible.

ğŸ“… Â React Native EU Conf with Guenther Steiner: Book LastÂ RegularÂ Tickets

Callstack sponsor

How to Build a GPT-3 App with Next.js, React, and GitHub Copilot â€” GitHub doesn't often run tutorials on its blog, but they appear keen to promote the idea of a modern Copilot-oriented developmentÂ process, and this certainly shows off some of theÂ potential.

Kedasha Kerr (GitHub)

Upgrading an Ancient React App
Jeffrey Carl Faden

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

a11y-dialog 8.0: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs â€” Supports alert dialogs as per WAI-ARIA, nested dialogs, and provides both a DOM and JavaScript API. Thereâ€™s a live CodeSandbox demo you can playÂ with. v8.0 no longer supports IE, if that's important toÂ you.

Kitty Giraudel

Mapkick.js: Interactive Maps in One Line of JavaScript â€” Supports Mapbox and MapLibre. It also comes in Python and Ruby variants targeting server-side rendered useÂ cases.

Andrew Kane

RxDB - Local Database For JavaScript Applications â€” With RxDB you can build realtime applications with great performance that even works when your users areÂ offline.

RxDB sponsor

PLJS: JavaScript Language Plugin for Postgres â€” PLV8 is the â€˜go toâ€™ extension to use JavaScript within Postgres, but this QuickJS-based variant, from the same creator, is more compact, easier to maintain, and may be enough forÂ yourÂ needs.

Jerry Sievert

Twin 3.4: Use Tailwind Classes in CSS-in-JS Libraries â€” Twin v3 introduced full Tailwind plugin support, and v3.4 adds a new SolidJS preset as well as styled-components 6Â support.

Ben Rogerson

Praxis: An iOS Browser That Blocks JavaScript â€” Well, thatâ€™s certainly one way to fight back against prompts, modals, and battery sapping scripts, but it wonâ€™t work with everyÂ site..

Arnold Sakhnov

Spectacle 10: A React and JSX-Based Presentation Library â€” Got a presentation coming up? Build your decks with JSX, perhaps. GitHub repo.

Formidable

ğŸ’» Jobs

Senior Software Engineer (Frontend Lead) â€” Come lead Emerge's web platform, used by teams like DoorDash, Square, Dropbox & Airbnb (our stack: Next.js, React, TS,Â Vercel).
ğŸ›¸ Emerge Tools

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

  • gridstack.js 8.4
    â†³ Framework agnostic dashboard layout and creation.

  • amqp-client.js 3.0
    â†³ AMQP 0-9-1 client for both Node and browser (via WebSocket).

  • FingerprintJS 4.0
    â†³ Browser fingerprinting library. No longer open source.

  • MQTT.js 5.0 â€“ MQTT client for Node and browser.

ğŸ™ˆÂ Taking things too far..

We'll support anyone who's keen to reduce the amount of needless JavaScript that goes over the wire (ğŸ‘‹ Astro or Qwik) but sometimes, just sometimes, you can go too far with the endeavor to almost comedic effect:

ğŸ˜± Â Implementing Tic Tac Toe with 170MB of HTML â€” Unsurprisingly, the demo (which weâ€™ve not linked to here) brought my browser to a crashing halt, but itâ€™s fun to see a developer take on the challenge of using Chromeâ€™s support for popovers and the state of said popovers along with a huge pile of HTML to handle a game of Tic Tac Toe. Donâ€™t repeat this in production,Â folks..

Gareth Heyes

#â€‹649 â€” July 27, 2023


Read on the Web



JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
Hono + Htmx + Cloudflare: A New Stack? â€” A lot of people seem to be jumping on htmx lately as an alternative to the complexity of frameworks like React, but what if you want to keep using JSX? Hono is a (vaguely Express-like) Web framework targeting edge function use cases and includes middleware for rendering JSX. Yusuke gives a quick example of how all this can come together with Cloudflare Workers and D1 for a simpler, full-stack JSÂ experience.
Yusuke Wada 


  
  
Shrinking VS Code with Name Mangling â€” Thereâ€™s a fair bit of JavaScript in VS Code but the team has managed to reduce the size of the shipped code by almost 4MB without actually doing any deleting or refactoring thanks to a new â€˜name manglingâ€™ build step. This is a great read on how the team approached things and got itÂ working.
Matt Bierner 


  
  
New Course: The Hard Parts of UI Development â€” Develop an under-the-hood knowledge of UI development by learning techniques such as data binding, UI composition, templating, virtual DOM and its reconciliation, and hooks, all fromÂ scratch!
Frontend Masters sponsor


  
  
Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses â€” A new project with some prominent names attached (the designer of C# and PM for TypeScript, for starters) that demonstrates the excitement within MS for large language models (LLMs). TypeChat aims to work around the problem of LLMs outputting hard-to-parse natural language and to direct such output into a predictable, typed form.
Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al. 


âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:
ğŸ¦ React/Redux's Dan Abramov is leaving Meta. Having achieved so much and reaching a point where he feels ready to move on, Dan is departing Meta but will remain on the React team as an independent thirdÂ party.Â ğŸ’™
ğŸ“˜ The Concise TypeScript Book is, unsurprisingly, a guide to using TypeScript. More surprisingly, it's all on GitHub and free to read. Hurrah.
Tixy is an interactive page for learning logic, math and expressions by solving puzzles using a visual grid. It starts off very simply, but gets elaborate quickly. This is a neat way to pick up some of the skills needed forÂ Dwitter.
JSPlayground is a new Web-based JavaScript sandbox tool.
Is the term 'Jamstack' finished? Brian Rinaldi wonders.


ğŸ‰ RELEASES:
Bun 0.7 â€“ The JavaScriptCore-based alternative JS runtime adds (experimental) Vite support, Web Workers support, and includes a --smol option to run in memory constrained environments (with a significant memory reduction shown off in theÂ post).
Astro 2.9 â€“ The 'zero JS by default' framework adds experimental support for view transitions and more.
Neutralinojs v4.13.0 â€“ Lightweight cross-platform desktop app framework.
Remix 1.19 â€“ Modern full-stack JS framework.
Node.js v20.5.0 (Current)


ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials





  
  
ğŸ’› Â 'Good Code is Like a Love Letter to The Next Developer Who Will MaintainÂ It' â€” â€œThe beauty of our creations, however, is not judged solely by the elegance of our algorithms or the efficiency of our code, but by the joy and ease with which others can build upon ourÂ work.â€
Addy Osmani 


More practically, Addy also tells us to stick to 'boring architecture' for as long as possible.





  
  
ğŸ“… Â React Native EU Conf with Guenther Steiner: Book LastÂ RegularÂ Tickets

How to Build a GPT-3 App with Next.js, React, and GitHub Copilot â€” GitHub doesn't often run tutorials on its blog, but they appear keen to promote the idea of a modern Copilot-oriented developmentÂ process, and this certainly shows off some of theÂ potential.
Kedasha Kerr (GitHub) 


  
Upgrading an Ancient React App
  
Jeffrey Carl Faden 
  


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools 




  





  
  
a11y-dialog 8.0: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs â€” Supports alert dialogs as per WAI-ARIA, nested dialogs, and provides both a DOM and JavaScript API. Thereâ€™s a live CodeSandbox demo you can playÂ with. v8.0 no longer supports IE, if that's important toÂ you.
Kitty Giraudel 


  
  
Mapkick.js: Interactive Maps in One Line of JavaScript â€” Supports Mapbox and MapLibre. It also comes in Python and Ruby variants targeting server-side rendered useÂ cases.
Andrew Kane 


  
  
RxDB - Local Database For JavaScript Applications â€” With RxDB you can build realtime applications with great performance that even works when your users areÂ offline.
RxDB sponsor


  
  
PLJS: JavaScript Language Plugin for Postgres â€” PLV8 is the â€˜go toâ€™ extension to use JavaScript within Postgres, but this QuickJS-based variant, from the same creator, is more compact, easier to maintain, and may be enough forÂ yourÂ needs.
Jerry Sievert 


  
  
Twin 3.4: Use Tailwind Classes in CSS-in-JS Libraries â€” Twin v3 introduced full Tailwind plugin support, and v3.4 adds a new SolidJS preset as well as styled-components 6Â support.
Ben Rogerson 


  
  
Praxis: An iOS Browser That Blocks JavaScript â€” Well, thatâ€™s certainly one way to fight back against prompts, modals, and battery sapping scripts, but it wonâ€™t work with everyÂ site..
Arnold Sakhnov 


  
  
Spectacle 10: A React and JSX-Based Presentation Library â€” Got a presentation coming up? Build your decks with JSX, perhaps. GitHub repo.
Formidable
